channel.title: Glock pistol sales surge after AZ shootings
channel.description:
After a Glock-wielding gunman killed six people at a Tucson shopping center on Jan. 8, Greg Wolff, the owner of two Arizona gun shops, told his manager to get ready for a stampede of new customers. Wolff was right. Instead of hurting sales, the massacre had the $499 semi-automatic pistols -- popular with police, sport shooters and gangsters -- flying out the doors of his Glockmeister stores in Mesa and Phoenix. “We’re at double our volume over what we usually do,” Wolff said two days after the shooting spree that also left 14 wounded, including Democratic Representative Gabrielle Giffords, who remains in critical condition. A national debate over weaknesses in state and federal gun laws stirred by the shooting has stoked fears among gun buyers that stiffer restrictions may be coming from Congress, gun dealers say. The result is that a deadly demonstration of the weapon’s effectiveness has also fired up sales of handguns in Arizona and other states, according to federal law enforcement data. “When something like this happens people get worried that the government is going to ban stuff,” Wolff said. Arizona gun dealers say that among the biggest sellers over the past two days is the Glock 19 made by privately held Glock GmbH, based in Deutsch-Wagram, Austria, the model used in the shooting. Sales Jump One-day sales of handguns in Arizona jumped 60 percent to 263 on Jan. 10 compared with 164 the corresponding Monday a year ago, the second-biggest increase of any state in the country, according to Federal Bureau of Investigation data. Handgun sales rose 65 percent to 395 in Ohio; 16 percent to 672 in California; 38 percent to 348 in Illinois; and 33 percent to 206 in New York, the FBI data show. Sales increased nationally about 5 percent, to 7,906 guns. Federally tracked gun sales, which are drawn from sales in gun stores that require a federal background check, also jumped following the 2007 massacre at Virginia Tech, in which 32 people were killed. “Whenever there is a huge event, especially when it’s close to home, people do tend to run out and buy something to protect their family,” said Don Gallardo, a manager at Arizona Shooter’s World in Phoenix, who said that the number of people signing up for the store’s concealed weapons class doubled over the weekend. Gallardo said he expects handgun sales to climb steadily throughout the week.

[b]Unfit to Stand Trial, Yet Fit to Have a Gun[/b]

By Rep. Louise Slaughter, Reader Supported News

Earlier today, Jared Loughner, a troubled young man who is accused of shooting 20 innocent people, including my colleague, Rep. Gabrielle Giffords, was found unfit to stand trial for his actions.

Mr. Loughner’s mental and emotional troubles have been well documented and were well known among classmates, professors and acquaintances well before Mr. Loughner opened fire on that fateful January day. Yet, despite the belief that Mr. Loughner could be a danger to himself and others, our federal laws, and our mental health system, were unable to live up to the commonsense belief that those who are mentally ill should not be able to purchase and own a gun.

Unfortunately, our nation’s gun lobby and their allies in Congress refuse to have an open and honest conversation about how to protect the rights of responsible gun owners, while being equally vigilant in protecting the rights of all Americans to assemble in peace.

Congress could start by considering proposed legislation that would prohibit those on the “no fly” list from buying a gun - something they are currently allowed to do. I’ve cosponsored this bipartisan legislation along with 24 colleagues (both Republicans and Democrats), yet we are still waiting for a vote on this bill.

Ultimately, our nation requires a mix of improved mental health services, improved information sharing among authorities, and a stricter control of the sale and possession of guns. Yet if we can’t even debate gun control legislation in our halls of Congress, then we will never be able to ensure that our children can go to school, to church or to the local grocery store and return safely home.

Today’s finding is the starkest sign yet that our nation’s gun laws are broken and need to be fixed. When our nation’s laws allow a troubled individual to purchase a gun, but can’t hold that same person responsible for their actions, then it is clearer than ever that we need to act.

[quote=“Thug-life, post:60, topic:377946”][quote author=jme link=topic=473828.msg3467246#msg3467246 date=1295026047]
We can’t carry guns here in Canada. That’s unfortunate because it’s so easy to get illegal guns here. I could leave my house and return with one 10 minutes later if I wanted.

So only criminals are allowed to carry guns here. Law abiding citizens who want to protect themselves or others are screwed.
[/quote]

See. I am against the legalisation of guns, but that is only in the case of the country I live in. I would likely, myself carry a gun too if I lived in the US (or at least certain states).

I understand the merits of it, and why people do carry guns for protection. My argument is that wiping them out as best as possible, reduces the channels in which guns are available to everyone. Make having a gun an extremely rare occurrence, and the chances of a criminal being able to get hold of one are significantly reduced.

I was watching a police documentary about firearm departments who specifically work to get rid of the illegal guns in the country, and would work on stopping them getting in. A large find of weapons, described by one of the police officers was 5 weapons - being the largest he had seen. That isn’t necessarily saying much, but what does is all the weapon busts were from people involved in high-level organised crime, not petty muggings or robbery.

I have said it before. I have never seen a gun in the UK not carried by a police officer or someone else in the armed forces. It’d be nice to keep it that way.[/quote]

I understand your point as well, and have considered how it would be to wipe out all guns (which would be completely impossible in a country like the USA with at least 300 million guns). There is a basic problem with that though, guns in the hands of law-abiding citizens aren’t just for protecting against criminals with guns. Even assuming a world where guns don’t exist, one or even a few young healthy people stand no chance against a gang of thugs; a sick, disabled, or old person stands no chance against a young healthy thug; and so on and so forth. Bring guns into that picture and they all have a chance where they would not previously, if you can pull a trigger, you can defend yourself.

@ large find of 5 guns, that’s crazy! Here they tend to over-exaggerate too, as I think they call 7 weapons an ‘arsenal’. I probably have 7 handguns myself, and at least 2, maybe 3 times that many long guns (shotguns, rifles, muzzle-loading rifles), I’d have to dig them all out for a complete accurate count.

Frell:

My only problem with our second amendment is the potential for public mass shootings. I support 6 month gun waits (even though it would just take a little longer for impulse shooters), higher bullet prices (will create black market though), and a fire rate limit on all semi automatic guns and no automatics whatsoever. You aren’t going to shoot a dear with an Uzi, they don’t need to be sold.

Actually restriction of our second amendments rights are the cause for most mass shootings, since, before this latest one in Arizona, basically all of them happened in so-called ‘no-gun zones’, (like schools, remember Virginia Tech? two of the first killed were concealed carry holders who couldn’t carry due to the law), where criminals are the only ones carrying guns.

@ wait times, they are useless. People who want a gun now would just buy it someplace else, such as from a private individual.
@ high bullet prices, never heard that one before, they are already extremely expensive, and do you think for one second that a criminal that makes their living with a gun wouldn’t gladly pay an extra cost to continue? How many criminals do you honestly think would go out and get a legitimate job simply due to the high price of ammo? It would be none. Not to mention it is trivial to reload your own ammo (make it yourself), I bought the equipment to do it a few years ago for about $80.

First of all, automatics currently aren’t legal for your average person to own, so that’s not an issue. Semi-automatics are ‘rate limited’ by how fast your finger can move, but making them slower wouldn’t accomplish a single thing. Do you know how easy it is to change that with nothing but a file? In fact, give me 10 minutes with about any semi-automatic and a file or grinder and I could make it fully automatic, anyone could, it’s easy. Also, I hear politicians all the time use the argument ‘you don’t need an assault rifle for deer hunting’, and I agree that hunting deer with an automatic wouldn’t work well at all, not to mention they are already illegal. The problem is there are many fine semi-auto rifles for deer hunting that are considered by some to be an ‘assault rifle’. I have 2 SKS’s for deer hunting, and AK-47s and AR-15s (civilian M16) are also great, accurate, and dependable rifles for hunting, so they DO need to be sold, there is nothing wrong with them or more dangerous than another gun.

Bottom line is less guns in the hands of criminals is good, but laws don’t accomplish that, they are already criminals and don’t follow laws. So the next best thing that can be done is put more guns in the hands of law-abiding citizens, and criminals instantly get less comfortable committing crime.
